Lectures Delivered Before Northwestern

Points to Good Season.

The lectures to be held this year
under the auspices of the history
department are of the same high
standard as in previous years. The
Albert Shaw lectures, which are for
the graduate students of the department, but not for the general public, will be delivered by Dr. Frank
A. Updyke, of the• University of
Dartmouth. The dates of these lectures have not yet been definitely
fixea, but they will take place shortly after the beginning of the second
term.
The James Schouler Foundation
lecturer for this year is Herr Joset
Redlich, professor of staatsrecht, or
constitutional law, at the University
of Vienna. He will deliver a series
of five lectures, from Monday, December 8 to Friday, December 12
—one each day of the week—in the
Donovan Room, at five o'clock P.
M. His general subject will be
"The Political Problems of AustriaHungary," which he will trace from
the time of the break between
Austria and Prussia and the foundation of the monarchy of AustriaHungary to the present day. Dr.
Redlich is the first lecturer to appear here under the Schouler Foundation since Professor Schouler
himself spoke here two years ago.
Due to the inability to find a suitable speaker, the course was discontinued last year, so that Dr. Redlich's talks will be followed with interest.
In addition to these lectures, the
Hon. Charles Francis Adams, of
Boston and Washington, will be
brought here by the history department to speak on the Civil War, on
which subject he is an authority.
Last season he delivered a course
of lectures on this subject at Oxford University, but later on he
found so much additional material
in London that he decided to lecture again on the same general
topic.
The regular University lecturers
to be seen here in the near future
are, likewise, men of note all over
the world. As has been announced
in a previous issue, Dr. Shosuke
Sato, of the University of Tokyo,
will be the second of the JapaneseAmerican Exchange lecturers to
speak in this country—the first being Dr. Inazo Nitobe, of the same
university. Dr. Sato will deliver
a course of six lectures dealing with
Japanese history and government,
the first to be held on Tuesday,
February 24.

The University musicians are
still persevering in their endeavors
to prepare a good program. Three
rehearsals were held by the Glee
Club at the dinner hours and a big
rehearsal on Saturday morning.
Great improvement has ben made,
especially in the observance of the
finer points of the music. The
Club still has two pieces to learn
before Christmas, and it will mean
plenty of hard work. Tenative lists
of the men who are doing good
work are being made, and those
who are irregular in attendance,
inattentive at rehearsals, or whose
singing is not up to the Club standard will be gradually eliminated
from the roll. Before any of the
trips are taken, it is being planned
to put each member of the Club
through an individual and single
rehearsal or examination, to make
sure that everyorje who goes on
the trips will be able to give music
worthy of Johns Hopkins University.
The instrumentalists are almost
ready for the concerts. They have
about mastered their pieces and
are practicing to make them perfect. Their only need now is several good "encores."
The first concert will be held in
the chapel of Goucher College, the
First M. E. Church, next Thursday night. The management has
a number of other plans in hand
for the winter season. The Christmas trip will probably be made
December 29 to 31 to Chestertown;
Dover, Del., and Salisbury. In
January a concert is being planned
for Sparrows Point, and a trip will
probably be made to Tome Institute. The manager also has proposals for a joint concert with the
University of Pennsylvania in February, but it has not yet been decided whether or not they will be
accepted. The McCoy Hall concert will likely be given late in
January or early in February for
the benefit of the 1914 "Hullabaloo."

A new book entitled "The Constitution of Matter," by Dr. Joseph
S. Ames, professor of physics and
director of the Physical Laboratory,
has just come from the publishers.
The body of the book is formed
of six lectures which Dr. Ames delivered at Northwestern University, last year. These were given
under the lectureship which was
founded in 1906 through the generosity of Mr. Norman Wait Harris, a wealthy banker of Chicago.
The purpose of the lecture
foundation is, as expressed by the
donor, "to stimulate scientific research of the highest type, and to
bring the results of such research
before the students of Northwestern University, and through them
to the world."
The titles of the lectures are:
I—"General Properties of Matter; Mass."
II — "Corpuscles and Atoms;
Electrical Mass."
III — "Radio-Activity; Gravitation."
IV—'Radiation; Formation of
Molecules; Elasticity."
V—"Properties of Metals; Thermionics; Magnetism."
VI—"Models of Atoms; Conclusions."
The fact that they were lectures
accounts for the form in which the
text is given; and the further fact
that the audience for whom they
were prepared was composed, for
a large part, of people unfamiliar
with both the facts and the methods of science, must be accepted
as the justification of the treatment
of the subject.
The main purpose of the lectures
was to make clear to a body of
people, not students of physics,
some of the results of'investigators
in unifying our knowledge of the
world around us. In book form
they should undoubtedly prove interesting to any reader.

The large number of candidates
who presented themselves at the
track team organization meeting
last Tuesday afternoon, and the
general display of enthusiasm and
spirit which has marked the first
practices, promises Captain Wagner and Coach England a very encouraging basis to work upon to
develop a successful team for the
cinder path this season. Between
sixty and seventy fellows, veterans
and novices, listened with growing
spirit to what Captain "Bod," the
coach and several other old hands
at the game had to say to them.
Captain Wagner opened the meeting with a short speech, in which he
expressed his gratification at the
large number of candidates, and his
hopes that they would all stick. He
then introduced the coach, who laid
especial emphasis, in his few remarks, upon the importance in track
work of sticking to it day after day,
week after week, and perhaps year
after year, and the possibilities of
surprising results from such earnest
work. He said he would leave to
others to speak of the pleasures of
track work and tell just a few
things that he had always been glad
were told him at the beginning of
his own track training. Patience
and perseverance he mentioned as
the qualities that count. He then
urged every man to think df and
work for Hopkins first and him:self second always, for team-work
counts for a great deal in track as
in every other sport.
Next, Manager Dorsey told the
men about the schedule that is being
arranged for this season. The
exact dates have not been set, but
the teams the Hopkins men are to
meet are practically decided upon.
The first contest will be the annual
indoor freshman - sophomore meet
to be held the last of January or
the first week in February. The
custom started last year of holding
indoor dual meets with different
athletic clubs of Baltimore will be
continued. A dual meeting with
Milton University of Baltimore will
also be held in .the Hopkins cage.
The feature of the indoor season
as usual will be the annual Fifth
Regiment Armory meet on February 14. The George Washing
ton meet at Washington and the
Georgetown meet will follow this;
the latter coming on March 7. The
outdoor season will include dual
meets with Navy, Swarthmore, Carlisle and Virginia, for none of
which the dates have been definitely

The 'Varsity won a brilliant victory from the men from Annapolis
on Thanksgiving Day. The game
was played at Cambridge and the
small crowd of rooters that accompanied the team made the air
black and blue as well, to St.
John's, with their cheering.
In the first half the two teams
played equally well and the ball was
worked up and down the field,
neither side being able to put over
a tally. The half closed with St.
John's in possession of the ball on
their 40-yard line. Lazenby was a
marvel at tackle, and it was his
work that kept St. John's from
scoring. In the second half, Johns
Hopkins University took a very decided brace and outplayed their opponents. The 'Varsity lost a good
many times on fumbles, but with
the ball in our possession on St.
John's 30-yard line, Captain Robinson took the ball around St. John's
left wing and scored the winning
touchdown. Hodges kicked goal.
Captain Robinson's run was only
accomplished by the matchless interference put up by Hodges and
Talty. Straus's work deserves decided credit. He broke up St.
John's formations repeatedly, and
it was greatly due to him and to
Lazenby that they did not score in
the first half.
When the final whistle blew, the
little band of Johns Hopkins University rooters went wild and tore
on the field and carried off the
players on their shoulders. There
was a great time in Cambridge that
night.

Debating Council Meets.

The Medical Standard Book Co.

The Debating Council met during the past week and selected the
subject which it will submit on December 9 to tile • Universities of
Virginia and North Carolina as its
choice for the annual triangular debate, which will be held this year
on Saturday, April 18.
.After quite a discussion, in which
a great range of subjects was considered, the Council unanimously
adopted the following: "Be it resolved that intercollegiate athletics
should be abolished by American
colleges. Virginia and North Carolina will also each present a subject.
The Council will begin active
work immediately after the holidays, when the class debating teams
will be picked. This year the debate between the two upper classes
will take place about the first week
in March. The subject will be the
same as that chosen for the intercollegiates, and the personnel of the
'Varsity team depends mainly on
the showing made in this debate.

Engineering Society Meets.

The regular bi-monthly meeting
of the Engineering Society, which
was postponed from November 24
on account of the football massmeeting, was held on Monday, December 1. Dr. Ames was the
speaker. He discussed in a rather
free way the present conditions in
the Tech. School, and enlightened
the members concerning many
things which concerned and affected them greatly. Dr. Ames also
outlined the work which has been
proposed for the third and fourth
year men in the departments of engineering, and at the close of his
talk answered questions which were
asked by various members.
Thirty-one students were in attendance and Dr. Ames was warmly applauded for his timely remarks.
The next meeting of the Society
will be held on Tuesday, December
9, at one o'clock. The lecturer will
be Dr. Pfund, who will read the
paper on "The Measurement of
Stellar Radiation," which he recently presented to the National
Academy of Sciences.
Secretary Leitheiser is now receiving applications for membership
in the Society.

BALTIMORE, MD., DEC. 8, 1913.
Anent Wednesday's Resolutions.

In the last four years of the life
of the collegiate department of the
Johns Hopkins there has been slowly, but persistently, developing what
Woodrow Wilson might term "a new.
freedom." It had its conception in
the agitation of the year preceding the formation of the Student
Council and has steadily and increasingly gone on since that time.
The students have n o w really
awakened to the responsibility and
opportunity that lies in student selfgovernment. In fact, the passage
of the resolutions at the mass-meeting last Wednesday would seem to
definitely assert that the undergraduates are willing—yes, anxious
—to undertake the management of
their own examinations — the first
step in the government of students
by Students. It is not strange that
it is distasteful to a student to feel
that a professor is watching all
through examinations. Undoubtedly, it is distasteful to the professor,
too, and he will heartily support the
student in saying:"We do not need
watching, we are an honorable body,
and any student who does not measure up to the standard, we will
throw him out!"
The gist of the resolutions which
were passed is:
1. "That the Student Council
* ,.* * be recognized to possess
the authority to take cognizance of
cases of dishonesty in examinations
and to take such action thereon as
*
it may deem proper." *
2. "That the Student Council,
though disclaiming the right to lay
on its individual members a * -* *
binding mandate of espionage, delation * * * do urge upon them
not only the moral justification, but
the praiseworthiness and necessity
as a matter of self-protection to the
honor of the student body, * * *

of seeing to it, when assured of the
occasion of dishonesty in examination, that the Student Council be
made aware thereof."
3. ''That the stddent body * * *
earnestly recommend to its individual members * * * to add
to examination papers the personal
assertion that assistance has been
neither given nor received." * * *
Here is the machinery in case
flagrant cases of dishonesty ever
come to light. Such cases would
certainly be noticed by more than
one witness; they would see a member of the Student Council, who
would have a meeting of the Council called a n d summary action
would be taken if deemed right.
THE NEWS-LETTER heartily approves of the resolutions and it
urges every student to take them to
heart and get behind them in earnest
support.
A New University at Homewood?

It is unfortunate for the University as it is about to move to Homewood that precedents of the undergraduates are being bowled over
annually. During the last six years
hazing has been carried on in a
secret manner on account of the
prejudices of the faculty; it has
led a haunted life with a single
grey-bearded ghost dogging along
at its heels, yet the drastic measures
instituted recently may be effective
in stamping out this custom and depriving the freshmen of what they
are most proud—of being one of
a few who are gently bathed of a
dark night in a nearby fountain.
Three years ago the interclass
cane rush was held for the last
time. No one was hurt, class spirit
rose to its height, the affair was
fairly judged by a senior committee; yet we are dumbfounded that
this innocent form of amusement
has been summarily discontinued.
On the following year the so-called
"class rush" was abolished by action
of a star chamber. This rush becomes a wrestling match two seconds after the whistle blows. The
undergraduates are taught wrestling by an instructor in the gymnasium ; but we are led to believe
that, by prohibiting the use of the
principles in public, which are
learned under cover of the gymnasium, the powers that prevail consider wrestling a thing not scholarly,
or a thing to be hidden like an undergarment, or a thing to arouse
Teutonic comment?
• This is all very well; but the
latest stab at our customs is the
lack this year of the freshmansophomore football game. The
"mild disabilities" imposed upon
the sophomore class are in pant the
cause; the refusal of the Homewood Committee to extend the use
of the field a week later has been
another setback. But before all
other reasons why the game could
not be played, this question must
be looked in the face: Is the undergraduate body allowing precedents
to go by the board without a mur-

mur?

ALUMNI NOTES

REVIEW OF ALUMNI MAGAZINE
Articles by Messrs.Lovejoy,Welch,Kelly,
Magoffin,Rogers, Vincent,Boyce,
Buchner and Keyes.

The Johns Hopkins Alumni
Magazine has successfully passed
through its infancy, having celebrated its first birthday at 'the beginning of the present scholastic
year. It is now beyond the experimental stage, and rests on the firm
foundation of a year's creditable
results, so that its future progress
will be watched with interest by the
alumni and students of our University.
The first number of the second
volume of the Alumni Magazine,
which appeared a few days ago,
is on a par with last year's issues.
In contains several particularly interesting and vital articles. The
editorial comment, especially that on
the selection of a president to fill
the vacancy caused by Dr. Remsen's
resignation almost two years ago,and
that on the hazing incident which
stirred up the whole University
recently, is to the point; and its
University notes are, in the main,
accurate. The leading article is a
. Lovejoy of
study by Prof. A. 06
the philosophy department, entitled
"Some Comparative Statistics Relating to the Graduate Department
of the University," in which the author, in an interesting, but necessarily technical manner, compares
former and present conditions existing in the graduate department
here, as regards numbers of teachers and students and relative cost
per student to the University. He
then goes on to contrast Hopkins
with other universities in these matters, showing that the cost per student here is greater than elsewhere,
and he comes to the conclusion that
a proper increase in annual expenditure "would not only permit a
marked increase in the University's
usefulness, but also be an important measure of economy in the administration of educational funds
in general." This study is followed
by an interesting, though not very
timely, article on Sargent's famous
painting of "The Four Doctors,"
namely, Drs. Halsted, Kelly, Osler
and Welch, which was presented to
the University in 1907 by Miss Garrett and now stands in the Donovan
Room. It contains reminiscences
of Dr. Welch and Dr. Kelly on
the way in which the group was
painted. In addition to these two
articles, Dr. Magoffin gives an account of the new Bureau of Appointments and its functions; Dr.
John M. Vincent recounts the origin
and growth of the American Historical Association and the general
connection of this University with
learned societies; and Mr. Lindsay
Rogers, A. B. '12, advocates a Bureau of Publicity, such as is found
in other universities. Finally, the
magazine contains three short articles: An outline of the progress at
Homewood during the summer, by
Mr. W. G. Boyce, '05, secretary of

DECEMBER 4, 1913.
To the, Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir—From a New York
newspaper I clip the following
item, which may be of interest:
Ithaca, N. Y., Wednesday—The "temptation number" of the Cornell Widow, the
huniorous magazine printed monthly by
Cornell undergraduates, has caused the
suspension of the editor-in-chief, Austin G.
Parker, of Helena, Mont., a senior in the
Arts College, and to the placing on probation of Archibald B. Johnston, of Pittsburgh, also a senior, by the Faculty Committee on Student Affairs.
- Complaints of alleged too up-to-date
reading matter and suggestive cartoons
and sketches were laid before the faculty,
in part, it is alleged, by members of the
Cornell Somerset Y., a temperance society
among the students which was made the
butt of ridicule in the Widow's editorials,
and by certain members of the faculty,
There is a strong undergraduate sentiment in favor of an appeal for the two
students, both of whom are prominent in
the university community.
The cover of the "temptation number"
depicted a scantily clad, good looking
young woman tickling the chin of a sombre
garbed gentleman wearing long whiskers.
The frontispiece depicted a charming
young woman in her night robe about to
go to bed, with this reading matter: "Because I'm in my nighty, and am of tender
age, oh, leave me to my modesty and
quickly turn the page."
The leading editorial was a condemnation of the reformers who voted to have
class banquets dry.

Shades of Lydia Pinkham! The
vice crusaders are even after the
college editors and publications.
Wouldn't it show a sufficient regard
for virtue if the faculty waited to
see whether the federal authorities
charged a misuse of the mails?
I sincerely trust that THE NEWSLETTER exchanges with The Widow. Recollections of .Life's improper number and the Harvard
Lampoon's famous cartoon of the
Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott and Mlle.
Eva Tanguay, both delightfully
deshabilks, are fresh in my memory.
If THE NEWS -LETTER has the
tempting Widow, can't it be placed
in Levering Hall with an asbestos
protection? Not to be read. Oh!
of course not—to heat coffee on
at the lunch hour.
May I, in conclusion, get a platitudinous, if not a particularly germane, moral off my chest? At
Hopkins, THE NEWS-LETTER, several times within my recollection,
has come near deeply injuring the
tender feelings of certain professors by remarks which were entirely innocuous and which at other
colleges, where there is more
undergraduate spirit, would have
passed absolutely unnoticed. My
moral, then, is this: When a student paper pokes fun at a pedagogue with the best of spirit, the
subject ought to smile and be flattered; when the fun is vindictive,
he ought to be a big enough man
to pass it over in silence. Examples of big and little men here
could be given, but why inveigle
THE NEWS-LETTER into difficulties?
I have too high a regard for its
charming and efficient editor-inchtef.
G. D.E.

The Pink Slips,
Boys!
How we like to
see them!

Dr. Smith's Book.

In a review in the current Hermathena, a publication of Trinity
College, Dublin, Ireland, the highest- praise is given to the latest book
of Prof. Kirby Flower Smith. The
book is entitled "The Elegies of
Albius Tibullus and the Corpus
Tebulliamene," and is characterized by the Hermathena as an "instance of that lightness of touch
by which the master is able to impress sweetness and light to the
most important discussions."
If we may judge by some extracts from this review, the notes
and introduction alone are fully as
fascinating as the text. "To read
them," remarks the reviewer, "even
without reference to the text, is an
education and a delight. . .
short, the notes are such a well of
Latin learning that one might declare (to adopt an old saying) that
the sauce was better than the fish.
. . . We congratulate the Johns
Hopkins University on the splendid
work of her distinguished professor of Latin."
"How do you do your meter
reading?"
"In volumes of gas."

The lectures to be held this year
under the auspices of the history
department are of the same high
standard as in previous years. The
Albert Shaw lectures, which are for
the graduate students of the department, but not for the general public, will be delivered by Dr. Frank
A. Updyke, of the• University of
Dartmouth. The dates of these lectures have not yet been definitely
fixea, but they will take place shortly after the beginning of the second
term.
The James Schouler Foundation
lecturer for this year is Herr Joset
Redlich, professor of staatsrecht, or
constitutional law, at the University
of Vienna. He will deliver a series
of five lectures, from Monday, December 8 to Friday, December 12
—one each day of the week—in the
Donovan Room, at five o'clock P.
M. His general subject will be
"The Political Problems of AustriaHungary," which he will trace from
the time of the break between
Austria and Prussia and the foundation of the monarchy of AustriaHungary to the present day. Dr.
Redlich is the first lecturer to appear here under the Schouler Foundation since Professor Schouler
himself spoke here two years ago.
Due to the inability to find a suitable speaker, the course was discontinued last year, so that Dr. Redlich's talks will be followed with interest.
In addition to these lectures, the
Hon. Charles Francis Adams, of
Boston and Washington, will be
brought here by the history department to speak on the Civil War, on
which subject he is an authority.
Last season he delivered a course
of lectures on this subject at Oxford University, but later on he
found so much additional material
in London that he decided to lecture again on the same general
topic.
The regular University lecturers
to be seen here in the near future
are, likewise, men of note all over
the world. As has been announced
in a previous issue, Dr. Shosuke
Sato, of the University of Tokyo,
will be the second of the JapaneseAmerican Exchange lecturers to
speak in this country—the first being Dr. Inazo Nitobe, of the same
university. Dr. Sato will deliver
a course of six lectures dealing with
Japanese history and government,
the first to be held on Tuesday,
February 24.

The University musicians are
still persevering in their endeavors
to prepare a good program. Three
rehearsals were held by the Glee
Club at the dinner hours and a big
rehearsal on Saturday morning.
Great improvement has ben made,
especially in the observance of the
finer points of the music. The
Club still has two pieces to learn
before Christmas, and it will mean
plenty of hard work. Tenative lists
of the men who are doing good
work are being made, and those
who are irregular in attendance,
inattentive at rehearsals, or whose
singing is not up to the Club standard will be gradually eliminated
from the roll. Before any of the
trips are taken, it is being planned
to put each member of the Club
through an individual and single
rehearsal or examination, to make
sure that everyorje who goes on
the trips will be able to give music
worthy of Johns Hopkins University.
The instrumentalists are almost
ready for the concerts. They have
about mastered their pieces and
are practicing to make them perfect. Their only need now is several good "encores."
The first concert will be held in
the chapel of Goucher College, the
First M. E. Church, next Thursday night. The management has
a number of other plans in hand
for the winter season. The Christmas trip will probably be made
December 29 to 31 to Chestertown;
Dover, Del., and Salisbury. In
January a concert is being planned
for Sparrows Point, and a trip will
probably be made to Tome Institute. The manager also has proposals for a joint concert with the
University of Pennsylvania in February, but it has not yet been decided whether or not they will be
accepted. The McCoy Hall concert will likely be given late in
January or early in February for
the benefit of the 1914 "Hullabaloo."

A new book entitled "The Constitution of Matter," by Dr. Joseph
S. Ames, professor of physics and
director of the Physical Laboratory,
has just come from the publishers.
The body of the book is formed
of six lectures which Dr. Ames delivered at Northwestern University, last year. These were given
under the lectureship which was
founded in 1906 through the generosity of Mr. Norman Wait Harris, a wealthy banker of Chicago.
The purpose of the lecture
foundation is, as expressed by the
donor, "to stimulate scientific research of the highest type, and to
bring the results of such research
before the students of Northwestern University, and through them
to the world."
The titles of the lectures are:
I—"General Properties of Matter; Mass."
II — "Corpuscles and Atoms;
Electrical Mass."
III — "Radio-Activity; Gravitation."
IV—'Radiation; Formation of
Molecules; Elasticity."
V—"Properties of Metals; Thermionics; Magnetism."
VI—"Models of Atoms; Conclusions."
The fact that they were lectures
accounts for the form in which the
text is given; and the further fact
that the audience for whom they
were prepared was composed, for
a large part, of people unfamiliar
with both the facts and the methods of science, must be accepted
as the justification of the treatment
of the subject.
The main purpose of the lectures
was to make clear to a body of
people, not students of physics,
some of the results of'investigators
in unifying our knowledge of the
world around us. In book form
they should undoubtedly prove interesting to any reader.

The large number of candidates
who presented themselves at the
track team organization meeting
last Tuesday afternoon, and the
general display of enthusiasm and
spirit which has marked the first
practices, promises Captain Wagner and Coach England a very encouraging basis to work upon to
develop a successful team for the
cinder path this season. Between
sixty and seventy fellows, veterans
and novices, listened with growing
spirit to what Captain "Bod," the
coach and several other old hands
at the game had to say to them.
Captain Wagner opened the meeting with a short speech, in which he
expressed his gratification at the
large number of candidates, and his
hopes that they would all stick. He
then introduced the coach, who laid
especial emphasis, in his few remarks, upon the importance in track
work of sticking to it day after day,
week after week, and perhaps year
after year, and the possibilities of
surprising results from such earnest
work. He said he would leave to
others to speak of the pleasures of
track work and tell just a few
things that he had always been glad
were told him at the beginning of
his own track training. Patience
and perseverance he mentioned as
the qualities that count. He then
urged every man to think df and
work for Hopkins first and him:self second always, for team-work
counts for a great deal in track as
in every other sport.
Next, Manager Dorsey told the
men about the schedule that is being
arranged for this season. The
exact dates have not been set, but
the teams the Hopkins men are to
meet are practically decided upon.
The first contest will be the annual
indoor freshman - sophomore meet
to be held the last of January or
the first week in February. The
custom started last year of holding
indoor dual meets with different
athletic clubs of Baltimore will be
continued. A dual meeting with
Milton University of Baltimore will
also be held in .the Hopkins cage.
The feature of the indoor season
as usual will be the annual Fifth
Regiment Armory meet on February 14. The George Washing
ton meet at Washington and the
Georgetown meet will follow this;
the latter coming on March 7. The
outdoor season will include dual
meets with Navy, Swarthmore, Carlisle and Virginia, for none of
which the dates have been definitely

The 'Varsity won a brilliant victory from the men from Annapolis
on Thanksgiving Day. The game
was played at Cambridge and the
small crowd of rooters that accompanied the team made the air
black and blue as well, to St.
John's, with their cheering.
In the first half the two teams
played equally well and the ball was
worked up and down the field,
neither side being able to put over
a tally. The half closed with St.
John's in possession of the ball on
their 40-yard line. Lazenby was a
marvel at tackle, and it was his
work that kept St. John's from
scoring. In the second half, Johns
Hopkins University took a very decided brace and outplayed their opponents. The 'Varsity lost a good
many times on fumbles, but with
the ball in our possession on St.
John's 30-yard line, Captain Robinson took the ball around St. John's
left wing and scored the winning
touchdown. Hodges kicked goal.
Captain Robinson's run was only
accomplished by the matchless interference put up by Hodges and
Talty. Straus's work deserves decided credit. He broke up St.
John's formations repeatedly, and
it was greatly due to him and to
Lazenby that they did not score in
the first half.
When the final whistle blew, the
little band of Johns Hopkins University rooters went wild and tore
on the field and carried off the
players on their shoulders. There
was a great time in Cambridge that
night.

The Medical Standard Book Co.

The Debating Council met during the past week and selected the
subject which it will submit on December 9 to tile • Universities of
Virginia and North Carolina as its
choice for the annual triangular debate, which will be held this year
on Saturday, April 18.
.After quite a discussion, in which
a great range of subjects was considered, the Council unanimously
adopted the following: "Be it resolved that intercollegiate athletics
should be abolished by American
colleges. Virginia and North Carolina will also each present a subject.
The Council will begin active
work immediately after the holidays, when the class debating teams
will be picked. This year the debate between the two upper classes
will take place about the first week
in March. The subject will be the
same as that chosen for the intercollegiates, and the personnel of the
'Varsity team depends mainly on
the showing made in this debate.

Engineering Society Meets.

The regular bi-monthly meeting
of the Engineering Society, which
was postponed from November 24
on account of the football massmeeting, was held on Monday, December 1. Dr. Ames was the
speaker. He discussed in a rather
free way the present conditions in
the Tech. School, and enlightened
the members concerning many
things which concerned and affected them greatly. Dr. Ames also
outlined the work which has been
proposed for the third and fourth
year men in the departments of engineering, and at the close of his
talk answered questions which were
asked by various members.
Thirty-one students were in attendance and Dr. Ames was warmly applauded for his timely remarks.
The next meeting of the Society
will be held on Tuesday, December
9, at one o'clock. The lecturer will
be Dr. Pfund, who will read the
paper on "The Measurement of
Stellar Radiation," which he recently presented to the National
Academy of Sciences.
Secretary Leitheiser is now receiving applications for membership
in the Society.

BALTIMORE, MD., DEC. 8, 1913.
Anent Wednesday's Resolutions.

In the last four years of the life
of the collegiate department of the
Johns Hopkins there has been slowly, but persistently, developing what
Woodrow Wilson might term "a new.
freedom." It had its conception in
the agitation of the year preceding the formation of the Student
Council and has steadily and increasingly gone on since that time.
The students have n o w really
awakened to the responsibility and
opportunity that lies in student selfgovernment. In fact, the passage
of the resolutions at the mass-meeting last Wednesday would seem to
definitely assert that the undergraduates are willing—yes, anxious
—to undertake the management of
their own examinations — the first
step in the government of students
by Students. It is not strange that
it is distasteful to a student to feel
that a professor is watching all
through examinations. Undoubtedly, it is distasteful to the professor,
too, and he will heartily support the
student in saying:"We do not need
watching, we are an honorable body,
and any student who does not measure up to the standard, we will
throw him out!"
The gist of the resolutions which
were passed is:
1. "That the Student Council
* ,.* * be recognized to possess
the authority to take cognizance of
cases of dishonesty in examinations
and to take such action thereon as
*
it may deem proper." *
2. "That the Student Council,
though disclaiming the right to lay
on its individual members a * -* *
binding mandate of espionage, delation * * * do urge upon them
not only the moral justification, but
the praiseworthiness and necessity
as a matter of self-protection to the
honor of the student body, * * *

of seeing to it, when assured of the
occasion of dishonesty in examination, that the Student Council be
made aware thereof."
3. ''That the stddent body * * *
earnestly recommend to its individual members * * * to add
to examination papers the personal
assertion that assistance has been
neither given nor received." * * *
Here is the machinery in case
flagrant cases of dishonesty ever
come to light. Such cases would
certainly be noticed by more than
one witness; they would see a member of the Student Council, who
would have a meeting of the Council called a n d summary action
would be taken if deemed right.
THE NEWS-LETTER heartily approves of the resolutions and it
urges every student to take them to
heart and get behind them in earnest
support.
A New University at Homewood?

It is unfortunate for the University as it is about to move to Homewood that precedents of the undergraduates are being bowled over
annually. During the last six years
hazing has been carried on in a
secret manner on account of the
prejudices of the faculty; it has
led a haunted life with a single
grey-bearded ghost dogging along
at its heels, yet the drastic measures
instituted recently may be effective
in stamping out this custom and depriving the freshmen of what they
are most proud—of being one of
a few who are gently bathed of a
dark night in a nearby fountain.
Three years ago the interclass
cane rush was held for the last
time. No one was hurt, class spirit
rose to its height, the affair was
fairly judged by a senior committee; yet we are dumbfounded that
this innocent form of amusement
has been summarily discontinued.
On the following year the so-called
"class rush" was abolished by action
of a star chamber. This rush becomes a wrestling match two seconds after the whistle blows. The
undergraduates are taught wrestling by an instructor in the gymnasium ; but we are led to believe
that, by prohibiting the use of the
principles in public, which are
learned under cover of the gymnasium, the powers that prevail consider wrestling a thing not scholarly,
or a thing to be hidden like an undergarment, or a thing to arouse
Teutonic comment?
• This is all very well; but the
latest stab at our customs is the
lack this year of the freshmansophomore football game. The
"mild disabilities" imposed upon
the sophomore class are in pant the
cause; the refusal of the Homewood Committee to extend the use
of the field a week later has been
another setback. But before all
other reasons why the game could
not be played, this question must
be looked in the face: Is the undergraduate body allowing precedents
to go by the board without a mur-

mur?

ALUMNI NOTES

REVIEW OF ALUMNI MAGAZINE
Articles by Messrs.Lovejoy,Welch,Kelly,
Magoffin,Rogers, Vincent,Boyce,
Buchner and Keyes.

The Johns Hopkins Alumni
Magazine has successfully passed
through its infancy, having celebrated its first birthday at 'the beginning of the present scholastic
year. It is now beyond the experimental stage, and rests on the firm
foundation of a year's creditable
results, so that its future progress
will be watched with interest by the
alumni and students of our University.
The first number of the second
volume of the Alumni Magazine,
which appeared a few days ago,
is on a par with last year's issues.
In contains several particularly interesting and vital articles. The
editorial comment, especially that on
the selection of a president to fill
the vacancy caused by Dr. Remsen's
resignation almost two years ago,and
that on the hazing incident which
stirred up the whole University
recently, is to the point; and its
University notes are, in the main,
accurate. The leading article is a
. Lovejoy of
study by Prof. A. 06
the philosophy department, entitled
"Some Comparative Statistics Relating to the Graduate Department
of the University," in which the author, in an interesting, but necessarily technical manner, compares
former and present conditions existing in the graduate department
here, as regards numbers of teachers and students and relative cost
per student to the University. He
then goes on to contrast Hopkins
with other universities in these matters, showing that the cost per student here is greater than elsewhere,
and he comes to the conclusion that
a proper increase in annual expenditure "would not only permit a
marked increase in the University's
usefulness, but also be an important measure of economy in the administration of educational funds
in general." This study is followed
by an interesting, though not very
timely, article on Sargent's famous
painting of "The Four Doctors,"
namely, Drs. Halsted, Kelly, Osler
and Welch, which was presented to
the University in 1907 by Miss Garrett and now stands in the Donovan
Room. It contains reminiscences
of Dr. Welch and Dr. Kelly on
the way in which the group was
painted. In addition to these two
articles, Dr. Magoffin gives an account of the new Bureau of Appointments and its functions; Dr.
John M. Vincent recounts the origin
and growth of the American Historical Association and the general
connection of this University with
learned societies; and Mr. Lindsay
Rogers, A. B. '12, advocates a Bureau of Publicity, such as is found
in other universities. Finally, the
magazine contains three short articles: An outline of the progress at
Homewood during the summer, by
Mr. W. G. Boyce, '05, secretary of

DECEMBER 4, 1913.
To the, Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
Dear Sir—From a New York
newspaper I clip the following
item, which may be of interest:
Ithaca, N. Y., Wednesday—The "temptation number" of the Cornell Widow, the
huniorous magazine printed monthly by
Cornell undergraduates, has caused the
suspension of the editor-in-chief, Austin G.
Parker, of Helena, Mont., a senior in the
Arts College, and to the placing on probation of Archibald B. Johnston, of Pittsburgh, also a senior, by the Faculty Committee on Student Affairs.
- Complaints of alleged too up-to-date
reading matter and suggestive cartoons
and sketches were laid before the faculty,
in part, it is alleged, by members of the
Cornell Somerset Y., a temperance society
among the students which was made the
butt of ridicule in the Widow's editorials,
and by certain members of the faculty,
There is a strong undergraduate sentiment in favor of an appeal for the two
students, both of whom are prominent in
the university community.
The cover of the "temptation number"
depicted a scantily clad, good looking
young woman tickling the chin of a sombre
garbed gentleman wearing long whiskers.
The frontispiece depicted a charming
young woman in her night robe about to
go to bed, with this reading matter: "Because I'm in my nighty, and am of tender
age, oh, leave me to my modesty and
quickly turn the page."
The leading editorial was a condemnation of the reformers who voted to have
class banquets dry.

Shades of Lydia Pinkham! The
vice crusaders are even after the
college editors and publications.
Wouldn't it show a sufficient regard
for virtue if the faculty waited to
see whether the federal authorities
charged a misuse of the mails?
I sincerely trust that THE NEWSLETTER exchanges with The Widow. Recollections of .Life's improper number and the Harvard
Lampoon's famous cartoon of the
Rev. Dr. Lyman Abbott and Mlle.
Eva Tanguay, both delightfully
deshabilks, are fresh in my memory.
If THE NEWS -LETTER has the
tempting Widow, can't it be placed
in Levering Hall with an asbestos
protection? Not to be read. Oh!
of course not—to heat coffee on
at the lunch hour.
May I, in conclusion, get a platitudinous, if not a particularly germane, moral off my chest? At
Hopkins, THE NEWS-LETTER, several times within my recollection,
has come near deeply injuring the
tender feelings of certain professors by remarks which were entirely innocuous and which at other
colleges, where there is more
undergraduate spirit, would have
passed absolutely unnoticed. My
moral, then, is this: When a student paper pokes fun at a pedagogue with the best of spirit, the
subject ought to smile and be flattered; when the fun is vindictive,
he ought to be a big enough man
to pass it over in silence. Examples of big and little men here
could be given, but why inveigle
THE NEWS-LETTER into difficulties?
I have too high a regard for its
charming and efficient editor-inchtef.
G. D.E.

The Pink Slips,
Boys!
How we like to
see them!

Dr. Smith's Book.

In a review in the current Hermathena, a publication of Trinity
College, Dublin, Ireland, the highest- praise is given to the latest book
of Prof. Kirby Flower Smith. The
book is entitled "The Elegies of
Albius Tibullus and the Corpus
Tebulliamene," and is characterized by the Hermathena as an "instance of that lightness of touch
by which the master is able to impress sweetness and light to the
most important discussions."
If we may judge by some extracts from this review, the notes
and introduction alone are fully as
fascinating as the text. "To read
them," remarks the reviewer, "even
without reference to the text, is an
education and a delight. . .
short, the notes are such a well of
Latin learning that one might declare (to adopt an old saying) that
the sauce was better than the fish.
. . . We congratulate the Johns
Hopkins University on the splendid
work of her distinguished professor of Latin."
"How do you do your meter
reading?"
"In volumes of gas."

In the Wake of Mrs. Pankhurst.

Happy, oh! happy, is Alice,
She thinks she has something to do,
Her sphere, she imagines, has widened,
For now she can vote with you.
But will the beneficent influence,
That now she intends to exert,
So suddenly spring into being,
When, before, her life was inert?
Her words, in the family councils,
Were, previously, forceless and flat.
Does she really think now for a moment,
He'll follow her taste for a hat?
